{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=1976 |Team=Kentucky Wildcats |Image=Uk_logo_preston_ursini.svg |Conference=Southeastern Conference |ShortConference=SEC |Record=8-4 |ConfRecord=4-2 |CoachRank=19 |APRank=18 |HeadCoach=[[Fran Curci]] |OffCoach= |DefCoach= |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Commonwealth Stadium (Kentucky)|Commonwealth Stadium]] |Champion= |BowlTourney=[[1976 Peach Bowl|Peach Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult= W 21-0 vs. [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]] }} {{1976 SEC football standings}} The '''1976 Kentucky Wildcats football team''' represented the [[University of Kentucky]] in the 1976 college football season. The Wildcats beat four different ranked teams during the season, scoring 209 points while allowing 151 points. Kentucky won the [[1976 Peach Bowl]] and finished the season 8-4 and ranked #19 in the country.
==Season==
Kentucky opened the season with a 38-13 victory over [[Oregon State Beavers football|Oregon State]]. Next was a 37-16 loss at [[Kansas Jayhawks football|Kansas]]. The following week, Kentucky defeated West Virginia 14-10.<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref>
On October 10,<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref> Kentucky hosted #20 ranked [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]].<ref>[http://www.kentucky.com/2011/09/04/1869157/mark-story-uk-footballs-greatest.html#storylink=mirelated Story, Mark, UK football's greatest wins at Commonwealth, Lexington Herald-Leader, September 4, 2011]</ref> The 57,733 in attendance was the largest crowd ever for a footabll game in the state of Kentucky up to that time.<ref>[http://www.kentucky.com/2011/09/04/1869157/mark-story-uk-footballs-greatest.html#storylink=mirelated Story, Mark, UK football's greatest wins at Commonwealth, Lexington Herald-Leader, September 4, 2011]</ref> Kentucky quarterback [[Derrick Ramsey]] ran for 95 yards and a touchdown; running back Chris Hill added 106 yards and a touchdown, and safety Rick Hayden had two intereceptions.<ref>[http://www.kentucky.com/2011/09/04/1869157/mark-story-uk-footballs-greatest.html#storylink=mirelated Story, Mark, UK football's greatest wins at Commonwealth, Lexington Herald-Leader, September 4, 2011]</ref> Kentucky held Penn State to 212 yards of total offense and won 22-6.<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref> Penn State coach [[Joe Paterno]] commented after the game, "That was a good football team we played. What can you say after you get the devil kicked out of you?"<ref>[http://www.kentucky.com/2011/09/04/1869157/mark-story-uk-footballs-greatest.html#storylink=mirelated Story, Mark, UK football's greatest wins at Commonwealth, Lexington Herald-Leader, September 4, 2011]</ref>
That victory was followed by a 14-7 loss at Mississippi State, a team that would finish the season with a 9-2 record.<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref> The following week, Kentucky defeated LSU 21-7.<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref> A 31-7 loss to Georgia was next, followed by a 24-14 loss at Maryland.<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref>
Kentucky went undefeated in November, defeating Vanderbilt 14-0 and Florida 28-9, and beating Tennessee 7-0 in [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville].<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref>
Kentucky finished the season in the [[1976 Peach Bowl]] against 9-2 [[North Carolina Tarheels football|North Carolina]],<ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref> ranked #18.<ref name="AP Poll Archive">{{cite web|title= AP Poll Archive| url=http://www.appollarchive.com| work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gYGhPijv|archivedate=2009-05-05|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-03-31}}</ref> Kentucky outgained North Carolina 334 yards to 109; the Wildcat defense held the Tar Heels to a total of five first downs and the Wildcats forced five turnovers.<ref name="Wildcats166">2001 Kentucky Wildcats Football Media Guide, '1976 Peach Bowl', p. 166</ref> Kentucky won 21-0 and ended the season ranked #19 in the AP poll.<ref name="AP Poll Archive">{{cite web|title= AP Poll Archive| url=http://www.appollarchive.com| work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gYGhPijv|archivedate=2009-05-05|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-03-31}}</ref><ref name="Wildcats166">2001 Kentucky Wildcats Football Media Guide, '1976 Peach Bowl', p. 166</ref><ref>[http://www.jhowell.net/cf/scores/Kentucky.htm#1976 1976 Kentucky Wildcats games and scores]</ref>
